sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: &app; is a simple backup program. It hides the complexity of doing backups the 'right way' (encrypted, off-site, and regular) and uses duplicity as the backend.

listitem.para: Support for the following backup locations:
Amazon S3
SSH server
Local folder
Automatically schedules backups at regular intervals.

sect2.title: When You Start &app;
sect2.para: When you start &app;, the following window is displayed.

textobject.phrase: Shows &app; main window. Contains titlebar, menubar, and display area. Menubar contains File, Edit, and Help menus.

sect1.title: Backing Up
sect1.para:
To backup, choose
File Backup . Or press the Backup button on the main window.
The Backup dialog is displayed. Click Apply to start the backup. A progress bar will appear. If an error occurs, the dialog will display an error message.

sect1.title: Restoring
sect1.para:
To restore, choose
File Restore . Or press the Restore button on the main window.
The Restore dialog is displayed. You first must pick where to put the restored files. You can either restore them to their original locations or put them under a folder of your choice.
After clicking Forward, you can review your restore options, then click Apply to start the restore. A progress bar will appear. If an error occurs, the dialog will display an error message.

listitem.para: Use this drop-down list box to specify the backup location that &app; uses when backing up or restoring. Select one of the following options:

This backup location uses the S3 storage service from Amazon. For a small fee per gigabyte, they hold your data for you. This is the recommended default because it is an easy way to keep your data offsite (meaning out of your home: in case of disaster or theft, your data will still be safe). You can sign up online.

caution.para: This service costs money. Read their rates carefully before using it.

listitem.para: This is the backup location to pick if you have an external hard drive that you want to use for backups.
If you have access to a server running SSH (a protocol that lets remote users log in), pick this location. Web hosts or data servers often provide SSH access.
Default: Amazon S3.

note.para: This option only appears if the Amazon S3 backup location has been selected.

listitem.para: Amazon S3 uses 'buckets' to keep your data organized. Each bucket is separate from the rest. Think of each bucket as a separate named remote hard drive. The default is deja-dup.

note.para: This option only appears if the Amazon S3 backup location has been selected.

listitem.para: This is your Access Key ID that Amazon gave you when you signed up for S3. It is like a username for logging into S3. If left empty, you will be prompted for it as you backup or restore.

note.para: This option only appears if the Local Folder backup location has been selected.

listitem.para: Choose the folder into which you want to store the backup files. This often will be an external drive that you plug in.

note.para: This option only appears if the SSH backup location has been selected.

listitem.para: Enter the username used to log in to the server.

note.para: This option only appears if the SSH backup location has been selected.

listitem.para: Enter the address of the server to use. This can either be an IP address (all numbers) or a domain name.

note.para: This option only appears if the SSH backup location has been selected.

listitem.para: Enter the SSH port for the server. This is almost always best left blank or as the default 22.

note.para: This option only appears if the SSH backup location has been selected.

listitem.para: Enter the directory to store backup files on the server.
Select a list of directories to backup. Press the Add or Remove buttons to modify the list. If you are only interested in backing up your own data, the default of Home Folder is sufficient.
Select a list of directories to not backup. Press the Add or Remove buttons to modify the list. This list takes precedence over the list of included directories.
Some of your data may be large and not very important to you. In that case, you can save yourself some time and space by not backing them up.

Encrypting your backup files is recommended to keep your data safe. If you don't have exclusive physical control of your backup location, or if it is stolen, an encrypted backup prevents others from looking at your personal data.
If on, you will be prompted for a password. Keep this password safe, you will need it to restore your data.
Default: On.

term.guilabel: Automatically backup on a regular schedule

listitem.para: Turn this option on to have &app; automatically backup for you. This is recommended so that you don't forget to backup. Backups are more useful the more recently you have made them, so it is important to regularly do so.
Default: Off.
Choose a schedule for automatic backups.
Default: Weekly.
